awd_titl_txt: Elements: MATPOWER for Integrated Smart Grid Research and Education
awd_abstract_narration:
The electric power system is one of the most fundamental and critical infrastructures underlying modern society, and the economic, environmental and societal impacts of advances in its planning and operations are potentially enormous. MATPOWER is a set of open-source scientific software elements for electric power system simulation, analysis and optimization. A version of MATPOWER is widely used, especially for research and education. This Cyberinfrastructure for Sustained Scientific Innovation (CSSI) Elements award supports the research needed to transition MATPOWER to a new flexible internal modeling architecture.  The new capabilities will enable MATPOWER to simulate and optimize integrated smart grid networks consisting of both transmission (balanced) and distribution (unbalanced) systems. These capabilities will serve to expand the scope of MATPOWER's future impact as a successful research tool for designing and analyzing the power systems of the future. As power grids evolve toward more sustainable, economically efficient and environmentally friendly systems, positioning MATPOWER to expand its role as a flexible research and educational tool in this arena of innovation and change has the potential for far reaching and transformative impact both nationally and globally.

MATPOWER addresses some of the most fundamental classes of problems in power systems analysis, namely the power flow, optimal power flow, and related problems used to determine the steady state voltages, currents and power flows arising from the interactions among system conditions, operator control actions and the laws of physics. The aim of this work is to broaden and extend MATPOWER's reach as a research-enabling tool for tackling future power systems problems in two specific ways. The first is to restructure the MATPOWER internals around a new unified MATPOWER element model, vastly expanding the range of devices and controls modeled by MATPOWER and further increasing its customizability. The second is to implement the modeling of multiphase unbalanced systems and integrated balanced and unbalanced models. This will expand the scope of MATPOWER?s usefulness to many current and emerging research areas related to the modern smart grid, with its proliferation of decentralized control and distributed energy resources (DER), such as solar PV, plug-in hybrid electric vehicles, local energy storage, and various kinds of actively managed demand.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This project set out to broaden and extend the reach of MATPOWER as a research-enabling tool for tackling future power systems problems (1) by redesigning the core MATPOWER software to enable more flexible user customization and facilitate significant user contributions, (2) by building on the new core architecture to enable modeling of multiphase unbalanced and hybrid networks, and (3) by supporting activities to further sustain and grow the MATPOWER user and developer communities.

The first goal was accomplished by designing and implementing an all-new flexible, modular architecture for MATPOWER's internals. This new object-oriented core is called MP-Core, and includes an explicit three-layer modeling structure, with separate decoupled layers for the data model, the network model, and the mathematical model. Two frameworks were developed for utilizing MP-Core. The legacy framework provides backward compatibility for legacy user customization features and validation using the extensive legacy test suite. The new flexible framework provides almost limitless user customization through the new MATPOWER Extension API.  Several proof-of-concept examples of unbalanced three-phase distribution and hybrid transmission/distribution models were implemented using this API. These examples, which solve power flow, continuation power flow, and optimal power flow problems for multiple formulations of each, demonstrate the power, flexibility, and simplicity of the new architecture and extension API. MATPOWER community support was provided through e-mail discussion lists, the MATPOWER web site, GitHub repositories and issue trackers, a webinar, and a new MATPOWER documentation site with an all new MATPOWER Developers Manual.

This project resulted in two new releases each of the MATPOWER Interior Point Solver (MIPS) and the MATPOWER Optimal Scheduling Tool (MOST), and six releases of the new MP-Opt-Model package, an open-source, Matlab-language, general mathematical modeling framework. MP-Opt-Model serves as the foundation for MP-Core's mathematical model layer but has broad applicability to problems far beyond electric power. The MATPOWER 7.1 and 8.0b1 releases, which include MIPS, MOST and MP-Opt-Model, were also direct outcomes of this project and have already been downloaded more than 114,000 times as of Feb 2023. The new MP-Core, legacy and flexible frameworks, proof-of-concept three-phase and hybrid examples, and other enhancements are all part of MATPOWER 8.
